awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: An Instrument and Adoption Framework for Student Cognitive and Social Engagement with a Course
awd_abstract_narration:
The Promoting Research and Innovation in Methodologies for Evaluation (PRIME) program seeks to support research on evaluation with special emphasis on: (1) exploring innovative approaches for determining the impacts and usefulness of STEM education projects and programs; (2) building on and expanding the theoretical foundations for evaluating STEM education and workforce development initiatives, including translating and adapting approaches from other fields; and (3) growing the capacity and infrastructure of the evaluation field.

This project supports engineering faculty in their efforts to develop, evaluate, and improve delivery of their courses.  The work is supported by the Course Social and Cognitive Engagement (CSCE) Framework.  The expected outcomes of this project are: (1) an exploratory framework for how engineering faculty make choices and engage in evaluation processes; (2) a deeper understanding of processes that underlie cognitive and social engagement in engineering classrooms; and, (3) a valid and reliable CSCE instrument with modular subscales to measure student engagement of STEM education.

por.por_cntn:
Recent research indicates student social engagement plays a pivotal role in the formation of engineers because it is central to many significant predictors of the academic and career success of engineering students. Although increased interest in social engagement is commendable, the data driving this research has been mostly reliant on analyzing the frequency and substance of social interactions observed among students. Prior to this study, there were no reliable instruments to measure the frequency and quality of students? social engagement inside and outside-of-the-classroom in relation to the activities associated with a specific course.

The purpose of this project was to develop a nuanced understanding of student social engagement and attempt to develop a survey instrument which measures social engagement vis-a-vis social capital. In this study, social capital is measured via three psychometrics: trust, reciprocity, and conduit-of-belonging.

Approach

Developed a psychometrically sound social engagement instrument, via three data collection rounds based on 1,130 responses from institutions in the US. Empirical results include findings for the Instrument, impact of social network to belongingness, and suggestions for integrating sustainability in teaching and students' research.

Engineering education and civil engineering education are the principal disciplines for which implications were found as explained belowed.

Instrument Development

The main outcome of the research is the social engagement survey which enables researchers to measure trust, reciprocity, and belongingness in a classroom setting. Results can be disaggregated by gender, race/ethnicity, age, year in college, and citizenship status. Data collected enables the examination of students' social networks: student to student, student to instructional staff, and student to other people.

The study also demonstrates how feedback from faculty, as it relates to the usability of the instrument and recommendations for improvement, impact the evolution of the Social Engagement instrument. The result allows an understanding of how the adoption of the instrument emerged through faculty input.

Overall, the developed instrument can help instructors better understand the social engagement within the classroom and can provide insightful information on the social network and channel of communication within a team. In the construction industry, this instrument can be helpful for the project manager to improve trust, reciprocity and belongingness among stakeholders of a construction project. 

Implications for Researchers

The project has impacts on social engagement, especially on trust, reciprocity, and belongingness. For trust and reciprocity, the study indicates that trust and reciprocity are important dimensions of social engagement. 

For belongingness, the study revealed that White construction undergraduate students often have a higher sense of class belonging than their African American classmates. Results also identify a significant relationship between a student?s class-level belonging and his/her group-level network centrality. The findings imply that a student who has a more central position in a study group may not have a higher sense of class belonging. Further, the findings suggest that SNA-based measurement is able to assess a student?s sense of class belonging. In addition, the project has provided an understanding on how collaboration influences member belongingness.  Construction undergraduate students have a stronger feeling of being valued when they work with partners from various disciplines because they often play a hub role. High belongingness in turn increases the likelihood of being successful for construction undergraduate students in academic studies. This explains why construction managers often perceive high belongingness when collaborating with interdisciplinary stakeholders.

Implications on Professional Formation

In addition, the project also helped develop future faculty and scholars. The PI helped one postdoctoral scholar improve his teaching skills. The postdoc has actively participated in teaching and supporting undergraduate and graduate courses; developed critical teaching skills such as communications with students, online lecturing, answering students questions and advising students on course projects; and has successfully built connections with external partners such as non-profit organizations, and operational departments to provide several real-world course projects for students. The postdoctoral scholar also worked on incorporating social components to an undergraduate course in cost estimation. Various literature have indicated that engineering students have difficulties articulating social issues. This unique experience has helped the postdoc be better prepared for his future faculty career.

The project also supported the development of future scholars via a symposium about research skills, especially for sustainability topics, The findings suggest that novice researchers experience confusion when evaluating and selecting research methods to support their investigation and illuminate teaching strategies that can strengthen students? sociotechnical problem-solving.

Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts

The project advances the understanding of social engagement in the classroom; contributes a framework to measure student social engagement with a course; allows the PIs and faculty participants to learn new approaches to measuring engagement that will inform their instructional strategies (PI & faculty behavior); and, by presenting findings within his/her university and at discipline-based conferences, contribute broadly to STEM educator development (faculty).
